questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue. During this time, he also has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss, which he attributes to poor appetite. He has not noticed any changes in his bowel movements or urination. He has hypertension well controlled with lisinopril. A colonoscopy 3 years ago and a CT scan of the chest 6 months ago showed no abnormalities. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 42 years. He is 174 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. There are firm palpable nodules in his left supraclavicular and periumbilical areas. Chest auscultation discloses no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Bowel sounds are normal. Which of the following studies is most likely to establish a diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A peripheral blood smear (PBS) can detect abnormal WBCs (e.g., blast cells, smudge cells) and has diagnostic value in patients suspected to have leukemia, which can manifest with lymphadenopathy (in lymphoid leukemias), anemia, and constitutional symptoms. However, the characteristic locations of lymphadenopathy in this patient are more consistent with a different type of malignancy, which cannot be diagnosed by PBS because it would most likely be normal or only show microcytes (since the anemia in this type of malignancy is caused by chronic blood loss and iron deficiency).

B) INCORRECT:

Prostate-specific antigen testing is performed as the first step in the diagnosis of prostate cancer, which is the most common malignancy in elderly men. However, spread to both the supraclavicular and periumbilical lymph nodes is an extremely rare initial manifestation of metastatic prostate cancer; this pattern of lymph node metastases is more consistent with a different type of malignancy.

C) CORRECT:

Palpable nodes in both the left supraclavicular region (Virchow nodes) and periumbilical area (Sister Mary Joseph node) are highly characteristic of metastatic gastric cancer. The diagnosis of gastric cancer is established by visualizing the primary tumor and obtaining a biopsy specimen during upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. Since most individuals with gastric cancer are initially asymptomatic or have nonspecific findings such as epigastric discomfort, nausea, weight loss, or anemia, this malignancy is usually diagnosed during later stages when metastatic spread and/or symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction become apparent.
Image Description:

Lymph is drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct primarily drains the upper right side of the body (green overlay). The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the rest of the body.

Testicular tumors do not typically disseminate to scrotal lymph nodes, because the two organs have separate lymphatic systems: testes drain to the para-aortic nodes and the scrotum drains to superficial inguinal nodes.

D) INCORRECT:

Lymph node biopsy (LNB) is used to diagnose lymphoma, which can manifest with constitutional symptoms, multiple noncontiguous enlarged lymph nodes (in non-Hodgkin lymphoma), and, in advanced disease, with anemia. However, the characteristic locations of lymphadenopathy in this patient are more consistent with a different type of malignancy, which cannot be diagnosed by LNB because it can only reveal the malignancy's histology but not its primary location.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest with contrast is the preferred initial step in the diagnosis of primary lung cancer. The characteristic locations of lymphadenopathy in this patient are more consistent with an extrathoracic primary tumor. In patients with this malignancy, a chest CT is performed to screen for additional intrathoracic metastases but it cannot establish the diagnosis.
questions.hint: The pattern of lymphadenopathy in this patient is highly characteristic of metastases from cancer in a particular location. The most common histological type of this malignancy is adenocarcinoma.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman with hypertension, type 2 diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease reports experiencing daily fevers up to 39°C for the past 2 weeks, along with drenching night sweats. She also lost approximately 9 kg during that time despite making no changes to her diet or physical activity. Her medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, rivaroxaban, metformin, and fluticasone-salmeterol. She has a 40-pack-year history of cigarette use but quit smoking 5 years ago. She does not consume alcohol or use illicit substances. She is a retired elementary school teacher and lives with her husband in New York City. She does not have any pets, has no history of international travel, and has never been homeless or incarcerated. A previous interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) was negative for evidence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
On physical examination, she is currently afebrile, and her vital signs are stable. She appears tired but not acutely ill. Her heart rhythm is irregularly irregular with no murmurs. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Her spleen tip is palpable, and her liver is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin. She has nontender bilateral axillary and inguinal lymph nodes measuring at least 1.5 cm. She has no rashes.
Routine laboratory testing is notable for a leukocyte count of 7300 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) and a hemoglobin concentration of 8.4 g/dL (12.0–16.0). Serum electrolyte levels and renal function were within normal limits.
Additional laboratory studies yield the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
58
0–35


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
46
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
230
30–120


Uric acid (mg/dL)
7.8
1.5–6.0


Angiotensin-converting enzyme (U/liter)
10
<40


HIV antigen/antibody
Not detected
Not detected


Epstein-Barr virus:




Capsid antigen IgM
Not detected



Capsid antigen IgG
Detected



Nuclear antigen
Detected



A chest radiograph is notable for paraseptal emphysema and mediastinal fullness.
Which one of the following evaluations is most likely to yield the correct diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Three sputum cultures stained for acid-fast bacilli
A fine-needle aspiration of an enlarged lymph node

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although fevers and night sweats are symptoms of active tuberculosis (TB), this patient has no risk factors for TB, has a negative interferon-gamma release assay, and does not have any radiographic findings that are typical of pulmonary TB. Therefore, sputum cultures for acid-fast bacilli would not be helpful in the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Fevers, night sweats, and weight loss are also symptoms of infectious endocarditis, which can be diagnosed by blood cultures and transesophageal echocardiography. However, this patient does not have a heart murmur or other clinical signs of endocarditis. Furthermore, although splenomegaly can be seen in patients with infectious endocarditis, diffuse lymphadenopathy would be very unusual. Blood cultures should certainly be obtained to exclude bacteremia but are not as likely as lymph-node biopsy to yield the correct diagnosis in this case because the patient’s clinical features are more suggestive of lymphoma.

C) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has a diagnosis of lymphoma. Factors that make lymphoma more likely in the setting of unexplained lymphadenopathy include age >40 years, lymphadenopathy in at least three body sites, and the presence of constitutional symptoms. White race and male sex are also risk factors. The diagnosis of lymphoma is best made by excisional lymph-node biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is inadequate to accurately diagnose lymphoma because it does not provide information about the lymph-node architecture, which is necessary to classify lymphoma; furthermore, it is prone to sampling error.

Key learning point: The best test to establish the diagnosis in a patient with multiple enlarged lymph nodes and several weeks of fevers, night sweats, and weight loss is excisional lymph-node biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

The diagnosis of lymphoma is best made by excisional lymph-node biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is inadequate to accurately diagnose lymphoma because it does not provide information about the lymph-node architecture, which is necessary to classify lymphoma; furthermore, it is prone to sampling error.

E) INCORRECT:

Fevers, night sweats, and weight loss are also symptoms of infectious endocarditis, which can be diagnosed by blood cultures and transesophageal echocardiography. However, this patient does not have a heart murmur or other clinical signs of endocarditis. Furthermore, although splenomegaly can be seen in patients with infectious endocarditis, diffuse lymphadenopathy would be very unusual. Blood cultures should certainly be obtained to exclude bacteremia but are not as likely as lymph-node biopsy to yield the correct diagnosis in this case because the patient’s clinical features are more suggestive of lymphoma.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with a two-month history of a painless swelling in his left supraclavicular region. He reports progressive fatigue and an unintentional 6-kg weight loss, but denies fever or night sweats. Physical examination reveals a firm, non-tender, 2-cm lymph node in the left supraclavicular fossa. Routine blood tests show mild anemia (see report).
Chest X-ray: No acute abnormalities
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis typically presents in adolescents and young adults with fever, sore throat, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient's age, absence of fever and pharyngitis, and presence of a solitary supraclavicular lymph node make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma often presents with painless lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats. Mediastinal involvement is common, but the patient lacks these features. The isolated supraclavicular node and normal chest X-ray do not align with typical Hodgkin lymphoma presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculous lymphadenitis often presents with tender, matted lymph nodes and systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats. The patient's firm, non-tender lymphadenopathy and absence of fever or night sweats, along with a normal chest X-ray, make tuberculosis unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

The presence of a firm, non-tender lymph node in the left supraclavicular region, known as Virchow's node, suggests metastatic spread from an abdominal malignancy, particularly gastric carcinoma. The thoracic duct facilitates lymphatic spread from the stomach to this area. The patient's symptoms, including unintentional weight loss, fatigue, and mild anemia, further support a malignancy diagnosis. These findings highlight the importance of correlating lymphadenopathy location with potential primary sources, indicating a metastatic process from the stomach.

Key learning point: Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy is highly suggestive of malignancy and warrants further investigation.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents with a three-month history of low-grade fevers, night sweats, and a 6-kg unintended weight loss to the clinic. He reports a painless enlarging mass in his left cervical region. Examination reveals a firm, non-tender 3-cm lymph node in the left anterior cervical chain. Blood tests show mild anemia (see report).
Imaging: Multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the neck and mediastinum
Which of the following diagnostic procedures is most appropriate to confirm the pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is primarily used for staging rather than initial diagnosis of lymphoma. It does not provide the nodal architecture and cellular details necessary for initial lymphoma diagnosis, especially when lymphadenopathy is present. Excisional lymph node biopsy is more appropriate for initial evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

Excisional lymph node biopsy is the preferred diagnostic procedure for suspected lymphoproliferative disorders, such as lymphoma, in patients with systemic 'B' symptoms and enlarged lymph nodes. This procedure involves removing an entire lymph node, preserving its architecture, which is crucial for histopathological analysis, immunophenotyping, and molecular studies. These evaluations are essential for accurately classifying lymphoma subtypes and guiding management. The comprehensive tissue sample obtained allows for detailed examination of cellular composition and architectural features, which are critical for differentiating between lymphoma subtypes.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected lymphoma with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy, an excisional biopsy of the lymph node is the preferred diagnostic approach to obtain sufficient tissue for histopathological examination and immunophenotyping.

C) INCORRECT:

Core needle biopsy provides limited tissue and may not preserve the nodal architecture necessary for accurate lymphoma diagnosis. The architectural features of lymph nodes are crucial for distinguishing between reactive changes and specific lymphoma subtypes, making excisional biopsy the preferred method.

D) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) provides a limited sample of cells without preserving tissue architecture, which is essential for diagnosing lymphomas. While useful for diagnosing metastatic lesions, FNA is inadequate for suspected lymphoma due to its inability to provide sufficient tissue for immunophenotyping and architectural analysis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with a painless, left supraclavicular swelling for two weeks. He denies fever or weight loss. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is less invasive but primarily yields cellular material without preserving tissue architecture. In suspected lymphoma, the architectural pattern is crucial for diagnosis. FNA's limitations in providing sufficient material for immunophenotyping and histologic analysis reduce its utility when comprehensive tissue sampling is needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics are typically used for acute bacterial lymphadenitis, which presents with tender, erythematous lymph nodes and systemic signs like fever. The patient's painless left supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, without systemic infection signs, suggests a noninfectious etiology requiring further diagnostic evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, especially on the left side, is concerning for malignancy due to its association with intrathoracic and abdominal cancers, as well as hematologic malignancies. In children, a painless, persistent node in this region necessitates a definitive tissue diagnosis to rule out conditions like lymphoma. Excisional biopsy is preferred as it allows for complete histopathological evaluation, preserving lymph node architecture, which is critical for differentiating between reactive processes and malignancies. This approach facilitates immunohistochemical studies and detailed morphological assessment, ensuring accurate diagnosis and guiding further management.

Key learning point: Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy is more concerning for malignancy in children compared to other lymph node locations.

D) INCORRECT:

While pediatric lymphadenopathy is often benign, the left supraclavicular location raises concern for neoplastic processes. The painless nature and absence of systemic symptoms do not exclude early malignancy. Observation alone risks delaying necessary diagnostic work-up, as benign etiologies in this region are less common.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a 10-week history of progressively enlarging lymph nodes in his neck. He reports a 15-pound unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months and occasional night sweats. Physical examination shows multiple hard, nontender, fixed lymph nodes in the posterior cervical triangle measuring 3–4 cm. Laboratory studies show normal complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel, and inflammatory markers. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer for early lymph node biopsy
Recommend flow cytometry of peripheral blood

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's clinical presentation with localized hard, fixed, nontender lymph nodes, constitutional symptoms (weight loss, night sweats), and progressive enlargement over 10 weeks strongly suggest malignancy. Lymph node biopsy is indicated to establish a definitive diagnosis when malignancy is suspected.

B) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry of peripheral blood typically has very low yield when a localized, solid lymph node malignancy is suspected, as in this patient. Peripheral blood involvement is uncommon at diagnosis in localized disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation is inappropriate when multiple features concerning for malignancy are present. The progressive enlargement over 10 weeks, hard consistency, fixation, and constitutional symptoms all warrant a more expedited management step.

D) INCORRECT:

Although testing for tuberculosis may be appropriate as part of lymphadenopathy evaluation, this patient's clinical presentation with localized hard, fixed, nontender lymph nodes and constitutional symptoms is more consistent with malignancy, particularly given that no risk factors for tuberculosis are mentioned. In addition, tuberculin skin testing is primarily used for latent tuberculosis screening in asymptomatic patients and may have a lower yield in patients with active infection, especially those with advanced disease, malnutrition, HIV, or another cause of immunosuppression.

E) INCORRECT:

A trial of empiric antibiotic therapy may be considered when a bacterial lymph node infection is suspected. However, this patient's clinical presentation with localized hard, fixed, nontender lymph nodes, constitutional symptoms, and progressive enlargement over 10 weeks suggests malignancy rather than bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 3-week history of painful left axillary swelling. She has also been experiencing low-grade fever and malaise over this period. Her mother reports that the swelling began about two weeks after a small, red bump appeared on her left forearm, which has since resolved.  She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are several, tender, nonfluctuant, markedly enlarged lymph nodes in the left axilla. The overlying skin is slightly erythematous. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. The patient has two healthy cats at home that she frequently plays with. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide supportive care and schedule follow-up in 2–4 weeks
Perform incision and drainage of the lymph nodes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is not a recommended antibiotic for cat scratch disease. While antibiotics may be considered for localized disease, azithromycin is preferred in immunocompetent patients. However, many patients do not require antibiotic therapy because the infection is self-limited.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound can help differentiate between benign and malignant lymph nodes but is not currently indicated in this patient because the clinical presentation strongly suggests infectious lymphadenopathy.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with classic localized cat scratch disease based on the history of cat exposure, characteristic timeline (skin papule followed by regional lymphadenopathy), and clinical findings. In immunocompetent patients with localized disease, treatment is often not required because the infection is typically self-limited and resolves within 6 months. Supportive care with close follow-up is appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are not indicated in this patient with characteristic features of localized cat scratch disease and a history of exposure to cats. Confirmatory studies, including serology, blood cultures, and/or histopathology are considered for the evaluation of extranodal cat scratch disease or when there is diagnostic uncertainty.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage of involved lymph nodes is avoided in cat scratch disease due to the risk of fistula formation. Aspiration may be considered for symptom relief in patients with painful suppurative lymph nodes but is not indicated in this patient with nonfluctuant lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a painless mass in her right axilla. She has noted progressive swelling in the area but has not had fever, night sweats, weight loss, or pruritus. She has no cough, dyspnea, or chest pain. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She emigrated from Peru five years ago. Family history is unremarkable. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears healthy. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 121/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, nontender, mobile 3-cm lymph node in the right axilla; there is no hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count and metabolic panel, are within normal limits. Excisional lymph node biopsy findings show hyaline vascular proliferation with regressed germinal centers and prominent capillaries. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Castleman disease is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by localized, non-tender lymphadenopathy, most commonly in the mediastinum or axilla. The unicentric form is typically asymptomatic, with normal laboratory findings, and involves a single lymph node. Histopathology findings show a regressed (atrophic) germinal center surrounded by concentric layers of small lymphocytes (onion-skin appearance) and prominent capillary proliferation with hyalinized walls. The disease is benign but may require surgical excision for definitive treatment.

Multicentric Castleman disease manifests with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss) and hepatosplenomegaly and is more common in patients with HIV and HHV-8 coinfection.

B) INCORRECT:

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, inflammatory skin disorder of the apocrine glands that manifests with painful, recurrent nodules, abscesses, and sinus tracts in intertriginous areas (e.g., axilla). This patient has an isolated painless mass, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

While tuberculous lymphadenitis can manifest with a firm, mobile lymph node in the axilla, patients typically also have constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fever, night sweats). Moreover, histopathology findings show caseating granulomas, rather than hyaline vascular proliferation with regressed germinal centers and prominent capillaries.

D) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma typically manifests with painless lymphadenopathy, often in the cervical or mediastinal regions, as well as B symptoms, splenomegaly or hepatomegaly, and focal or generalized pruritus. While this patient has cervical lymphadenopathy, he does not have pruritus, B symptoms, or organomegaly. Moreover, histopathology findings show Reed-Sternberg cells (large cells with binuclear or bilobed nuclei with dark centers of chromatin and pale halos, which result in an owl-eye appearance), rather than hyaline vascular proliferation with regressed germinal centers.

E) INCORRECT:

Cat scratch disease (CSD) manifests with swollen, tender lymph nodes in the axilla. However, CSD follows exposure to an animal (most commonly a cat) scratch, bite, or saliva and is often accompanied by constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, myalgias). Additionally, histopathology findings in CSD show granulomatous inflammation with central stellate microabscesses, rather than hyaline vascular proliferation or regressed germinal centers.
questions.hint: This condition may involve a single region of lymph nodes (unicentric) or multiple regions of lymph nodes (multicentric). Multicentric disease is common in patients with HIV.
